text: Oh thats okay :) Take your time. Sorry If I have disturbed you.
keeping calm under pressure can be tough. In a work environment, it is generally pressure of either 1) deadlines, or 2) very challenging work.

large workloads with short deadlines can seem overwhelming. the way to deal with that is to break the problem down into manageable chunks and deal with them in turn. It may still be a lot of work, but if each bit seems reasonable, the whole combination can seem to be more reasonable.
So I like to think of reports as just a collection of sections, each section is easy to write, so the whole report is easy to write.

challenging work can cause pressure if it seems like it is impossibly difficult. The way I deal with that is to reverse the thought - difficult work is a challenge, and I enjoy a challenge! So for example, the reason my work at the moment is intense is I have been asked to contribute to a project that I know nothing about, on a subject I know nothing about. The relevant skill I have is interpreting academic maths papers, so I am learning new concepts and applying my skills in a new way. There is a lot of pressure to get the work done soon and a report out, but I like the challenge of learning new things, so I am enjoying it.

The general lesson from that I think is to take a step back from what is causing the pressure, work out why it is causing an issue, and try to find a way to reverse that issue. So for the first example, it could be the size of the project that is causing pressure, so just break the project down into manageable chunks and you defeat that.
